There is one major concern many astronomers are having right now. The the wide angle camera (some 35°~) is a marvel of science. Unfortunately we are growing in and around ourselves with technology. There are now and will be thousands more points of light interfering with the electronics on long exposure photographs. The StarLink network currently has 1,500 satellites scattering around low earth orbit @ 550 km up. The cone of reflection toward the sun side will certainly spoil many image attempts. This is a worldwide problem. Amazon (Bezos) has the ULA agreement to launch 3,236 satellites. (Project Kuiper). China's StarNet plans to launch 10,000 satellites in the next five years. It is clear that the skies will not be clear.

I think it's worth clarifying that while it's sensitive enough to see a golf ball to the distance of the Moon, it can't actually resolve it. It'll just be few slightly brighter pixels on the background of blackness of space, where one pixel would cover 380m x 380m area. To resolve two golfballs as two objects rather than one they would have to be 1.3km apart from each other. That's based on the published seeing limit of 0.7 arc seconds and pixel size of 0.2 arc seconds.

At 3:10 she says that "If we were able to put a golf ball at the same distance as the moon, we would be able to see it". That is totally untrue. That would require a resolution of 100 picoradians, (4cm/400000km) which would require a primary mirror of the order of 10^10 wavelengths, about 5 kilometers (Rayleigh diffraction limit).
